commits.message:
Reserve Billing Credits on Workflow Execution

This commit moves the billing service client into the metering entity and makes a call to reserve credits when
the metering reserve call is make from the engine. This reduces touch points within the engine such that it makes
a single reserve call to metering and credits are automatically handled.

Currently the credit type is inferred from the capability type. This is hard-coded for now for demo purposes only.

prs.title: cannon: Return EAGAIN error when writing to a EventFd file descriptor
prs.truncated_body:
**Description**

Improve the stubbing of `SysEventFd` sys call by making it return a marker file descriptor (`^Word(0)`) instead of `0`. Read and write calls to that file descriptor always return `EAGAIN` error.

Note that based on the actual observed behaviour of the go runtime, the error code is set in `v0` and `v1` is set as a flag for whether there is an error or not. That is the opposite

prs.title: op-supervisor: Prevent ErrOutOfScope to Bubble Up Across Chains
prs.truncated_body:
Based on a finding located here:

https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/issues/16016

## Problem
When checking doing `HazardSafeFontierChecks`, each dependency checks `CandidateCrossSafe`, which has the potential to return `ErrOutOfScope`.

If `ErrOutOfScope` is returned, it is bubbled up to the canddiate-scoping of the *original* chain, creating an inappropriate scope bump.

## S

feat: implement core storage transaction support + in-memory implementation (#1674)

## Description

Breakout from the larger PR #1673

## Changes

**Note:** This PR _only_ affects test-related code. The new transactions
are _not used_ in any actual tests here (see the other PR for that),
with the exception of the handful of new tests explicitly testing the
transactional functionality for the in-mem store.

Highlights:
- `SharedStore` now implements `Transactable` which lets you call
`begin_transaction()` to get an `InMemoryTransaction` handle, which you
can `commit()` or `rollback()`.
- `DbRead` is implemented for both `SharedStore` and
`InMemoryTransaction` in `read.rs`.
- `DbWrite` is implemented for both `SharedStore` and
`InMemoryTransaction` in `write.rs`.
- The implementations for `InMemoryTransaction` are just delegating
calls to the `SharedStore` implementations, i.e. super boilerplate.

More details:
- Restructured the `storage` module a bit:
  - `in_memory.rs` migrated to `memory` folder.
_(I had originally just named this `in_memory` but ran into issues with
the Emily container builds complaining about duplicate modules, despite
that not being true... 🤷 )_.
- Split `DbRead` and `DbWrite` implementations into `read.rs` and
`write.rs` to try to manage file size and separate the logical
implementations.
- Core "store" logic is in `store.rs` (i.e. `Store` and `SharedStore`).
- New traits:
- `Transactable`: Implemented for stores which can create transactions
(i.e. our `SharedStore` and `PgStore`).
  - `TransactionHandle`: Implemented for transaction handle types
- New types:
- `InMemoryTransaction`: Represents a transaction for the in-memory
database and implements `TransactionHandle`. It uses a simple, naive
optimistic concurrency check for concurrent transactions. Also
implements `DbRead` and `DbWrite`.
- `SharedStore` now implements `Transactable`, giving it
`begin_transaction()` capabilities.

fix: sign stacks tx once per tenure per request (#1691)

## Description

Closes: https://github.com/stacks-sbtc/sbtc/issues/1659

## Changes

Added (yet another) LRU to tx signers keeping the stacks "requests"
signed for each bitcoin tenure -- I went with a max size of 2, probably
1 would be enough as well. Also I went with the in memory solution
instead of the db since it's not something we need persistence for, as
we already only invoke the validation if the message comes from the
current coordinator.

On stacks tx signature request validation, we first check if it's known.
And after the signature broadcast, we add mark the request as signed.

~This covers only deposits and withdrawals, we could also add it for key
rotations but since it was not as susceptible to the issue as the others
I skipped it.~

## Testing Information

Added an integration test.

fix: skip DKG if latest shares are unverified (#1705)

## Description

Currently if we need to DKG because of config changes we will keep doing
DKGs until we get a confirmed rotate key tx. But if we don't manage to
DKG + verify + rotate key submission in the same bitcoin tenure, we will
"discard" the previous progress and just start a new round.

## Changes

Prevent DKG if latest shares are unverified.

Add Workflow to Deploy Emily (#1681)

This PR deploys emily off specific branches (ones that match the
`environment/*` pattern).

Requirements:
- [x] Add environments in the `sbtc` repository each containing the
required environment variables and secrets for the respective
environment (the environment names have to match the branch names from
which the deployment is made):
  - `environment/devnet`
  - `environment/staging`
  - `environment/private-mainnet`
  - `environment/mainnet`
- `approve-emily-deployment` (used only to require a manual approval
before the deployment takes place, no variables/secrets have to be added
here)
  
Workflow jobs:
- `Build & Diff Emily` - This job prints a diff of the changes in GitHub
Step Summary, which has to be reviewed before proceeding
- `Approve Emily Deployment` - This job waits for the manual approval of
the workflow before proceeding with the deployment
- `Deploy Emily` - This job builds Emily then deploys it, only runs
after the approval step is successful.

Test runs:
- Emily deployment to devnet through this workflow:
https://github.com/BowTiedDevOps/sbtc/actions/runs/15139506011
- Colored diff output in step summary (performed after the devnet
deployment, hence I've cancelled the workflow):
https://github.com/BowTiedDevOps/sbtc/actions/runs/15140197457#summary-42561938508

**IMPORTANT NOTE:** This PR can be safely merged, but the mentioned
environments have to be created before their respective deployment
branches are published.

refactor: improve epoch_manager error handling and logging (#1697)

1. Increases log verbosity for key operations in `process_queue` (finding slots, waiting, sending txs) by changing several `trace!` calls to `info!`.
2. Modifies error handling within the main loop:
- Errors encountered during the rollover check (`check_for_epoch_rollover`) are now logged as errors but no longer cause the `process_queue` function to return immediately.
- Failures during `send_batched_transactions` are also logged as errors, but the function now continues processing the epoch instead of returning the error. This makes the forester more resilient to transient transaction send issues.
3. Removes a redundant `TODO` comment.

- Implements lockup-based tribute claiming to support transferable NFT lockups where tributes follow the lockup rather than the original voting user
- Adds migration logic to transition from the existing user-based tribute claims to the new lockup-based system using `TRIBUTE_CLAIMED_LOCKS`
- Introduces new query endpoints to track voting history and claimable amounts at the loc
